page.title: 08Geology of the Eryrys area.
page.content: The area around Eryrys is a block of carboniferous limestone, which dips under the millstone grit of Mynydd Du. Rock outcrops line the north and north west in the Special Scenic and Scientific Interest area on Bryn Alyn. A small area of limestone pavement lies within the S.S.S.I. A series of parallel mineral veins run across the area from the north west to the south east. The most important being the Belgrave and Westminster veins to the north and south of Eryrys respectively. The veins contain lead ore (galena) and calcite. They are no longer worked and most of the mine shafts have been capped. Granite erratic boulders are found close to Eryrys village. The one at Maendigychwyn is claimed to be the second largest in North Wales.
